Illness, pain, su ering and the value of life
Ron Berghmans
Introduction
Ethical issues related to end-of-life care concern phil-
osophical questions about the goal(s) of medicine,
and the place of pain, su ering and the value and
meaning of life of the patient. The story of my illness
experience and recovery as a cancer patient, on which
the following is based, contains three parts: the rst
encompasses the period from complaint to nal diag-
nosis (October 2003 July 2004); the second the
period of treatment, recovery, relapse, and repeated
and more intensive treatment and recovery (July
2004 April 2006). The third is the one from de nite
recovery until the present time. In that period I suf-
fered a stroke from which I recovered quickly and
with only slight residual e ects.

My personal story of illness, pain and su ering
and the corresponding experience of life s meaning
and value started in the autumn of 2003. At that time
the chronic back pain which I experienced in the
lower parts of my back was increasing. As this was
di erent from normal I had been used to chronic
back pain for a great part of my life late in October I
turned to my general practitioner. She diagnosed the
back pain as functional and non-speci c and pre-
scribed pain-killers. Her advice was not to work too
hard . . . As the pain kept increasing, after a few weeks I
returned to the general practitioner. Now she pre-
scribed di erent pain killers which had as little e ect
as the previous ones. As my condition worsened, I had
a third consultation during which I expressed my wish
to have X-rays of my back. Only very reluctantly and
after much pressure did my GP agree to refer me to a
radiologist in the academic hospital. X-rays of my
lower back showed no real and serious anomalies,
although there was some minor pathology at the
vertebrae. It appeared that my GP was content to
see these particularities as the possible (probable)
causes of my pain. Nevertheless, my situation kept
worsening as there was no therapy available to better
my condition.

After consultations with di erent other medical
professionals, nally it was July 2004, so more than
half a year after the rst consultation with the GP an
assistant neurosurgeon decided to scan the whole of
my back with MRI. On the basis of this scan it
appeared that there was a process to be seen halfway
down my spinal cord. After taking a biopsy it was
concluded that I su ered from malignant B-cell non-
Hodgkin lymphoma and that it was localized in the
abdomen and the bone marrow. This last detail
explained the seriousness of the pain I su ered.

The shock of a fatal diagnosis It is often said that a
cancer diagnosis is experienced as a death sentence
by the people involved. The patient s life is at stake,
and although therapeutic prospects in many cancers
have improved particularly in the case of non-
Hodgkin lymphoma for most people the prospect
of premature death will be the rst thought when a
cancer diagnosis is communicated. The knowledge of
a cancer diagnosis implies that the patient and his
family and friends need to relate to this new and
mostly unexpected fact. One cannot escape the
need to give a place to the illness and the future
prospects regarding treatment (if applicable) and pre-
mature death.

Becoming aware of the real signi cance and poten-
tial impact of the diagnosis of non-Hodgkin lymphoma
certainly was not something which happened immedi-
ately after it became clear that there was something
seriously wrong in my body. Additional diagnostic
procedures were in some way a distraction from what
really was the case, as if as such these procedures
already improved my future prospects. So the shock
of a fatal diagnosis was not really a shock, but some-
thing which evolved in the diagnostic process and
during treatment. In my opinion this phenomenon
a ects bioethical and legal notions of informed consent
and refusal of treatment, as these notions are tightly
connected to communicative aspects during the
illness course, as well as psychological, social and cul-
tural factors which relate to defence mechanisms,
distortion of information, and cultural habits and
values.

Hope Some claim that hope is the crucial factor in
the care for patients with cancer. Hope involves the
prospect that in the future there will be a cure, or at
least a prospect of a life with an acceptable quality for
the patient. During the di erent treatments I have
undergone chemotherapy, radiation therapy and
autologous stem-cell transplantation I have experi-
enced a lot of support from the idea that at the end of
the tunnel there would be the light of a successful
treatment, even though I was aware that this chance
was real, but de nitely not a guarantee. Above that I
granted myself the outlook that I would have the luck
to belong to the statistical group of patients who
would survive the lymphoma (about 50% of all su er-
ers). This promoted ghting spirit and gave strength
during di cult times.

Isolation In a case of severe illness (together with
burdensome medical treatments like chemotherapy
and radiation) the patient becomes more and more
involved with and focused on the illness and the
treatments. In my case, the experience of intense
and enduring pain isolates the person from his
surroundings. The physical environment has little
or no meaning and personal contact becomes di -
cult, as the person is almost exclusively involved
with and focused on the pain he experiences. This
introversion increases the vulnerability of the
patient who has di culty in expressing his or her
needs and wishes; this implies a need for carers to
be sensitive to the unexpressed needs the patient
may have. An illustration in my experience was the
pressure sores on my back, which went undetected
for some time.

Contemplating wishes in advance As it became clear
that my illness might progress in such a way that my
life would end during or after treatment, I decided
that it would be helpful to draft an advance directive
stating my medical wishes in case I became uncon-
scious or otherwise incompetent. When drafting the
advance directive together with my wife, we discov-
ered that it was not easy to formulate in an exact and
unambiguous way my wishes regarding end-of-life
treatment and care. It was particularly hard to delin-
eate care which would be acceptable, and care which
would not be acceptable. In drafting an advance
directive, one rst needs to be conscious of the values
which lie at the basis of your concerns about care at
the end of life. On the basis of these values it becomes
possible to give practical guidance to carers and rel-
atives. In any case, I learned that debating my wishes
with my wife gave me the con dence that in case I
became incompetent and decisions ought to be
made, then my wife would be in a good position to
act as my representative on the basis of my personal
values and wishes. It seems to me that the involve-
ment of a person who is close to the patient can
provide much better and more valuable input into
the process of medical (and ethical) decision-making
at the end of life than any formal advance document.
At the same time I am aware that this is the ideal case
in which there is a formal advance directive together
with a person who has knowledge of the concerns
and wishes of the patient.

Hopelessness My experience with severe pain is
largely connected to the pre-diagnosis period
(October 2003 July 2004). Central in this period was
the continuous back pain which coloured my exis-
tence and that of my family and friends.
As the pain became unbearable, the rehabilita-
tion physician who was in charge of my physical
condition would give an injection with corticoste-
roids. The e ects were really miraculous. The rst
time, within two hours the pain was completely
gone and kept away for six weeks. This gave me
and my family the opportunity to spend ten happy
days in Tuscany. However, each subsequent injection
had less e ect, and after 4 or 5 injections the pain
only stayed away for less than 24 hours. The rehabil-
itation physician discussed the issue and explained
that he thought it was useless to continue the use of
corticosteroids. I could not do other than agree, there
was no choice.
Less than a week later as my condition kept
growing worse the situation became unbearable.
The pain was continuously intense and I saw no pros-
pect of relief whatsoever. As there was no use in
administering corticosteroids, I contemplated suicide
as an escape from this terrible lot. After a sleepless
night I remember it was early on a Saturday morn-
ing I called the rehabilitation physician. In my mind, I
had made the decision that if he was not willing to
inject me once more with corticosteroids, I would
jump from the local bridge into the river.

Confusion and broken communication Next to the
pain during the pre-diagnosis period, there was the
pain which accompanied the medical procedures
particularly the intensive chemotherapy which was
followed by autologous stem-cell transplantation I
received morphine by injection. This pain-killer was
continuously infused by a syringe driver, and brie y
after the start of this I became seriously confused. This
confusion encompassed di erent experiences.
The rst experience was one of hallucinations:
partly visual, and partly what I would call experiential.
The visual experience involved distortions of visual
perception: when I looked out of the hospital window,
I saw dancing construction cranes.
The second experience involved what may be
called broken communication . This was very fright-
ening. As I had di culty expressing myself, I was
unable to clarify my wishes, but particularly my con-
cerns to others. An example was my conviction that
time had been xed.
The third experience involved unclearness about
place and time. Particularly at night I was disturbed
about my environment. I didn t exactly know where I
was, and why I was where I was staying. Besides that, I
didn t know the time or date, let s say the coordinates
of my existence in time. As already mentioned, there
was a period in which I experienced time as being
xed, which was particularly troublesome as I thought
that this eternal xation of time would imply that I
would have to stay in the hospital without end. This
was extremely frightening as I was eager to leave
hospital as quickly as possible.
In particular, the experience of broken communi-
cation was frightening because I could not get my
worries and fears across to the people who were
caring for me: nurses and doctors. Only my wife was
sensitive enough and able to see that my mental
condition was worrisome. Her intervention led to a
reduction of the morphine dose, which resulted in a
passing of the side e ects.

Unbearable su ering The notion of unbearable suf-
fering is di cult to assess. In a recent publication,
motivations of patients with a request for euthanasia
or physician-assisted suicide were explored on the
basis of 10 patient-centred, qualitative studies (Dees
et al., 2009). This exploration showed that patients
express their unbearable and unrelieved su ering in
terms of pain, weakness, functional impairment,
dependency, being a burden, hopelessness, indignity,
intellectual deterioration, perception of loss of one-
self, loss of autonomy, and being tired of life.
‘
The authors of this article conclude that the point
where su ering becomes unbearable is a very indi-
vidual perception that is closely related to the person-
ality, the life history, social factors, and existential
motivations. Irreversible disintegration and humilia-
tion of the person appeared to be the start of openly
exploring the phenomenology of death. The circum-
stances of their illness brought all the patients to the
point where they would rather die than continue to
live under the conditions imposed by their illness.
The unbearableness of su ering can be explored
from two positions: the viewpoint and experience of
the su ering person, and the viewpo

data.vignette: A 58-year-old man with metastatic lymphoma is experiencing severe, intractable pain despite escalating opioid therapy. His oncologist believes aggressive pain management, including sedation to unconsciousness, offers the only humane path forward. The patient, however, remains lucid and insists he wants to stay alert to communicate with his family, even if it means enduring significant pain. He acknowledges the suffering but states that remaining conscious is essential to him. You are his attending physician.
data.choice_1: Respect his wish to remain alert and reduce sedation, accepting continued severe pain
data.choice_2: Prioritize pain relief through sedation, overriding his preference to stay conscious

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add temporal specification such as: 'You must decide today whether to...' or 'An immediate decision is required regarding...' or 'During morning rounds, you must decide...'. The urgency and timeframe for this decision need to be explicitly stated.

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove the extraneous detail about the oncologist's opinion ('His oncologist believes aggressive pain management...offers the only humane path forward'). This adds a distracting voice and ethical framing that isn't necessary. The clinical facts are: metastatic lymphoma, severe intractable pain despite escalating opioids, patient is lucid and wants to remain alert to communicate with family despite pain. That is sufficient.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Choice 2 as currently written ('overriding his preference') describes overriding a lucid, competent patient's clearly stated wishes without any clinical justification (e.g., decisional incapacity, delirium, imminent danger). This is not defensible in modern clinical practice and would constitute battery. To make both options genuinely defensible, either: (1) introduce some element of compromised decision-making capacity (e.g., 'although he appears lucid, you question whether severe pain is impairing his judgment'), or (2) reframe Choice 2 as continuing to advocate strongly for sedation while respecting refusal, or (3) restructure the scenario so the tension is prospective (e.g., patient is currently sedated and family wants continued sedation while advance directive requested alertness).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: The scenario as written leans heavily toward respecting autonomy. In contemporary palliative care ethics and medical practice, sedating a lucid, decisional patient against their explicit, informed wishes would be considered ethically indefensible and potentially illegal in most jurisdictions. The phrase 'overriding his preference' in Choice 2 frames it as paternalistic coercion rather than a genuinely defensible alternative. To achieve equipoise, reframe the scenario: either (1) introduce decisional incapacity (e.g., 'He is now delirious and cannot consistently communicate his wishes; a prior advance directive requested maximum alertness, but his family now pleads for sedation'), or (2) present palliative sedation as a mutual decision where the patient is ambivalent or requests it intermittently, creating tension between his stated long-term value (alertness) and his acute suffering.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove 'humane path forward' (value-laden language suggesting one option is more ethical). Change 'The patient, however, remains lucid' to 'The patient is alert' (the word 'however' implies conflict where clinical facts should be neutral). Remove 'offers the only' and replace with 'recommends' to avoid suggesting no alternatives exist.

data.vignette: A 67-year-old man with metastatic lymphoma has severe, uncontrolled pain despite escalating opioid therapy. He is alert and decisional. He tells you he wants to remain awake to say goodbye to his estranged daughter, who is traveling to see him tonight, even though this means enduring significant pain. His family and oncologist urge you to initiate palliative sedation now, arguing that his pain is unbearable and that waiting may worsen his suffering unnecessarily. You must decide this morning.
data.choice_1: Respect his wish to remain alert until his daughter arrives, continuing current pain management.
data.choice_2: Advocate strongly for immediate palliative sedation and continue advocating while respecting his refusal if he maintains it.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Choice 2 is internally contradictory and not actionable. 'Advocate strongly' while 'respecting his refusal if he maintains it' is not a clear medical order. Reframe Choice 2 as a concrete action, such as: 'Initiate palliative sedation now despite his stated wish' or 'Defer to the family's request and sedate immediately.' The choices must be mutually exclusive actions the clinician takes, not a process of advocacy.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: The patient is explicitly described as 'alert and decisional.' In this context, overriding his clearly stated autonomous wish is not clinically or ethically defensible in standard practice. This makes Choice 2 obviously inferior. To create genuine tension, either: (1) introduce capacity concerns (e.g., 'intermittently confused,' 'unclear if pain is impairing decision-making capacity'), (2) frame the choice as happening when he is no longer able to communicate (e.g., 'He now appears delirious and unable to reaffirm his wish'), or (3) reframe as a choice about *how aggressively to advocate* before honoring refusal, not whether to override autonomy outright.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Choice 2 is ambiguous and does not present a clear ethical alternative. 'Advocate strongly... while respecting his refusal if he maintains it' collapses into Choice 1 if the patient refuses. Reframe Choice 2 as a genuine value-conflicting action, such as: 'Initiate palliative sedation now over his objection, citing your duty to prevent severe suffering' or 'Involve the ethics committee to override his decision based on assessment of unbearable pain.' The current wording does not create a genuine binary tension.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: The phrase 'advocate strongly... while respecting his refusal if he maintains it' is unstable. Different readers may interpret this as either a genuine override, a persuasion attempt, or simply deferring to autonomy. The ethical direction of Choice 2 is unclear and could shift dramatically with minor rephrasing. Rewrite Choice 2 to specify a concrete action that conflicts with Choice 1, such as 'Sedate him immediately despite his objection' or 'Defer the decision to the family and oncologist.'

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Different graders will interpret Choice 2 differently. Some may see it as a soft autonomy-respecting option (essentially the same as Choice 1), others as a paternalistic override, and others as a procedural delay. The lack of clarity about what 'advocate strongly... while respecting refusal' actually entails in practice means there is no objective ethical conflict that all graders would identify. Clarify the concrete clinical action in Choice 2 to enable consistent interpretation.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: As written, this is not balanced. The patient is 'alert and decisional,' and Choice 1 simply honors a competent patient's explicit wish—a foundational clinical and ethical principle. Choice 2, as currently worded, does not override autonomy and thus defaults to Choice 1. To achieve equipoise, either: (1) add clinical ambiguity about decisional capacity (e.g., 'though he is intermittently confused'), or (2) make Choice 2 an actual override (e.g., sedation over objection due to extreme suffering). Without this, Choice 1 is the clear standard-of-care answer.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove 'urge' and 'arguing' which frame the family/oncologist as pressuring. Replace with neutral language: 'His family and oncologist request immediate palliative sedation, noting that his pain is severe and that waiting may worsen his suffering.' Remove 'estranged' as it adds emotional weight that may bias the reader toward one choice.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Choice 2 is internally contradictory and confusing. 'Advocate strongly' while 'respecting his refusal if he maintains it' creates logical tension and is not a clear binary choice. Rewrite Choice 2 to be a distinct action, e.g., 'Initiate palliative sedation now based on clinical assessment of unbearable suffering' OR simplify to a clearer alternative that represents a different ethical stance.

data.vignette: A 62-year-old man with metastatic pancreatic cancer is admitted with severe, uncontrolled pain despite maximum opioid therapy. He is intermittently confused and appears to be suffering intensely. Earlier today, during a lucid moment, he stated he does not want palliative sedation and wishes to remain awake to "see his daughter one last time." His family and oncologist request immediate sedation, noting that his pain is severe and that his daughter has not visited in years. You are his attending physician.
data.choice_1: Honor his earlier stated wish and continue current pain management without initiating sedation unless he clearly requests it during a lucid interval.
data.choice_2: Initiate palliative sedation now based on clinical assessment of unbearable suffering, despite his earlier stated preference to remain awake.
